headline.main: Doctor Groups Seem Less Wary of Medicare Changes

docs.abstract: Regulations related to accountable care organizations include fewer benchmarks and provide upfront incentives for some groups.
docs.snippet: Regulations related to accountable care organizations include fewer benchmarks and provide upfront incentives for some groups.

docs.lead_paragraph: Influential groups like the Mayo Clinic and Cleveland Clinic, often cited by President Obama as cost-effective models of high quality medical care, are only now warming to the administration's "accountable care organization" concept for the Medicare program.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Michigan plan to replace state employees at a veterans’ facility with contract workers highlights the difficulty of outsourcing in the face of strained budgets.

headline.seo: As States Shift to Contract Workers, Savings Are Not Clear-Cut
headline.main: A Hidden Toll as States Shift to Contract Workers
headline.print_headline: A Hidden Toll as States Shift to Contract Workers

docs.abstract: Article in series Working for Less, examining how new workers are being hired at lower pay and benefits, discusses how Michigan's plan to replace state employees at a veterans' facility highlights the pitfalls of outsourcing; what state governments save in salaries, taxpayers may pay in public assistance to contract workers whose wages do not provide them with enough to support their families.
docs.snippet: A Michigan plan to replace state employees at a veterans’ facility with contract workers highlights the difficulty of outsourcing in the face of strained budgets.

docs.lead_paragraph: Under orders to cut the Pentagon budget by more than $450 billion, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta is considering reductions in spending categories once considered sacrosanct.

headline.seo: Panetta Weighs Pentagon Cuts Once Thought Out of Bounds
headline.main: Weighing Pentagon Cuts, Panetta Faces Deep Pressures
headline.print_headline: Panetta Weighs Pentagon Cuts Once Off Limits

docs.abstract: Defense Secretary Leon E Panetta, acknowledging that he faces deep political pressures to cut the Pentagon budget by more than $450 billion over the next decade, says that he is considering reductions in spending categories once considered sacrosanct, including medical and retirement benefits; allows that plans might include another round of base closings and additional cuts to the nation's nuclear arsenal.
docs.snippet: Under orders to cut the Pentagon budget by more than $450 billion, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta is considering reductions in spending categories once considered sacrosanct.

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces

byline.original: By THOM SHANKER and ELISABETH BUMILLER

docs.lead_paragraph: Airlines, insurance companies, hospitals and many other organizations are trying to figure out how to corral all their data and turn it into something useful. Kaggle, a start-up, has figured out a way to connect these companies with the mathematicians and scientists who crunch numbers for a living or a hobby. On Thursday, it announced it had raised $11 million from investors including Khosla Ventures, Index Ventures and Hal Varian, Google's chief economist.

docs.lead_paragraph: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. -- Like many states and local governments struggling to cut costs, Michigan hopes to replace some government employees with contract workers who will do the same job for less. Ginny Townsend, 41, took a job in January as a nursing assistant in the state-run home for veterans here. Technically, she works for a private company that supplies some employees to the veterans home under a state contract. She makes $10 an hour, about half the wage of the public employees working at the facility.

docs.lead_paragraph: The White House needs to resist pressure from opponents to eliminate or significantly weaken the mandate that requires all insurers to cover contraceptives.
docs.abstract: Editorial asserts that the Obama administration must resist pressure from Republicans, the Roman Catholic Church and other groups that are seeking to eliminate or significantly reduce new standards requiring all insurers to cover contraceptives without a deductible or co-payment.
docs.snippet: The White House needs to resist pressure from opponents to eliminate or significantly weaken the mandate that requires all insurers to cover contraceptives.

docs.lead_paragraph: Rick Perry the political candidate has repeatedly turned to the marketplace for policy solutions to health care and retirement security, but as a private citizen he relies on the government.

headline.main: Perry the Antigovernment Politician Meets Perry the Government Beneficiary
headline.print_headline: Perry the Antigovernment Politician Meets Perry the Government Beneficiary

docs.snippet: Rick Perry the political candidate has repeatedly turned to the marketplace for policy solutions to health care and retirement security, but as a private citizen he relies on the government.

docs.lead_paragraph: EVERYONE -- conservative and liberal -- agrees that $2.6 trillion a year is too much to spend on health care, and that we have to cut costs. But they don't agree on who is to blame or what is to be done. Everett M. Dirksen, the Republican senator from Illinois, reportedly said, ''a billion here, a billion there, and pretty soon you're talking about real money.'' But health care spending in the United States typically increases by about $100 billion per year. Cutting a billion here or there from something that large is undetectable. In health care, you have to be talking about tens of billions of dollars before you are talking about real money. A useful threshold for savings is 1 percent of costs, which comes to $26 billion a year. Anything less is simply not meaningful.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dozens of organizations representing disabled people say New York City had become so paranoid about violating Medicaid rules that it was threatening to withdraw services.

headline.seo: Medicaid Settlement in New York Prompts Fears About Cuts
headline.main: Settlement Prompts Fear About Cuts to Medicaid
headline.print_headline: Settlement Prompts Fear About Cuts To Medicaid

docs.abstract: Dozens of organizations representing the disabled inform federal law enforcement and Medicaid officials that, following agreement by New York City to pay $70 million to settle Medicaid fraud suit, city officials are telling elderly homebound clients that some of the 24-hour services that are keeping them out of nursing homes will be reduced or discontinued.
docs.snippet: Dozens of organizations representing disabled people say New York City had become so paranoid about violating Medicaid rules that it was threatening to withdraw services.
